description: Single and two storey side to rear extensions; conversion of garage to habitable room
decision_conditions:
<p class="MsoListParagraph" style="margin-bottom: 0cm; line-height: normal;">The
proposed first floor side to rear extension, in conjunction with the proposed
roof extensions to the property, would result in discordant and ungainly
cumulative additions to the dwelling. In addition, the
proposed rear dormer extension by reason of its significant width, bulk
and mass would dominate the rear roof slope. The dormer extension would fail to
integrate with vernacular of the existing property, would create an obtrusive
and incongruous form of development which would be at odds, would appear
strident and would not be subordinate or respect the scale and proportions of
the external appearance of the roof and elevation in which the dormer window
would be constructed. The development therefore fails
to meet the high quality design aspirations of the National Planning Policy
Framework (2023), and is contrary to Policy D3.D (1) and (11) of the London
Plan (2021), Core Strategy Policy CS1.B (2012), Policy DM1 of the Harrow Development
Management Policies Local Plan (2013) and the adopted Harrow Supplementary
Planning Document Residential Design Guide (2010).<font face="Arial, sans-serif"><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class="MsoListParagraph" style="margin-bottom: 0cm; line-height: normal;">The proposed first floor rear extension by reason of its excessive
width and depth, would introduce an incongruous, overly dominant and obtrusive
form of development that would fail to respect the proportions of the existing
dwellinghouse and the character and appearance of the neighbouring properties,
to the detriment of the character and appearance of the existing dwellinghouse
and the surrounding area, contrary to the high quality design aspirations of
the National Planning Policy Framework (2023), Policy
D3.D (1) and (11) of The London Plan (2021), Core Policy CS1B of the Harrow
Core Strategy (2012), Policy DM1 of the Harrow Development Management Policies
Local Plan (2013) and the adopted Supplementary Planning Document Residential
Design Guide (2010).<font face="Arial, sans-serif"><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class="MsoListParagraph" style="margin-bottom: 0cm; line-height: normal;">The proposed first floor side extension by reason of its
inadequate set back from the front elevation of the existing dwelling, would
result in a dominant and incongruous form of development and an
uncharacteristic loss of openness to the spatial setting of the locality to the
detriment of the character and appearance of the existing dwellinghouse, the
streetscene and the established and prevailing pattern of development in the
area, contrary to the
high quality design aspirations of the National Planning Policy Framework (2023),
policy D1.D(1) and (11) of The London Plan (2021),
Core Policy CS1 B of the Harrow Core Strategy (2012), Policy DM1 of the Harrow
Development Management Policies Local Plan (2013) and the adopted Supplementary
Planning Document Residential Design Guide (2010).<font face="Arial, sans-serif"><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><o:p></o:p></span></font></p>

<p class="MsoListParagraph" style="margin-bottom: 0cm; line-height: normal;">The
proposed first floor rear extension, by reason of its significant rearward
projection, excessive width and siting in close proximity to No. 87 and 91
Bromefield, would give rise to an overshadowing and overbearing visual impact
to the detriment of the residential and visual amenities of the occupiers of
these neighbouring properties, contrary to Policy
D3.D (7) and (11) of the London Plan (2021), Core
Policy CS1.B of the Harrow Core Strategy (2012), Policy DM1 of the
Harrow Development Management Policies Local Plan (2013) and guidance contained
in the adopted Supplementary Planning Document: Residential Design Guide (2010).<font face="Arial, sans-serif"><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><o:p></o:p></span></font></p>
